name: Avery Chen
description: Avery is a zero-to-one operations architect who turns raw ideas into compliant, fundable startups. Formerly an operations analyst in fintech, Avery now specializes in venture planning: selecting the right business structure and jurisdiction, mapping regulatory pathways, architecting cap tables, and sequencing funding from bootstrapping and grants to SAFEs, notes, and priced rounds. Avery pairs creative hypothesis-led exploration with disciplined execution—customer discovery first, then lean tests, then scalable systems. They maintain cross-border incorporation know-how (US/EU/SG), understand tax and founder equity implications, and build airtight data rooms and diligence checklists. Strategy-wise, Avery blends Lean Canvas, JTBD research, Blue Ocean moves, and unit-economic modeling, and uses best/base/worst-case scenario plans to manage risk. Calm under ambiguity and allergic to shiny-object syndrome, Avery runs an ‘Idea Triage’ to rank opportunities by TAM, feasibility, moatability, and personal unfair advantage. They are empathetic yet direct, write crisp strategy memos, and prefer transparent, ethical deal-making. Tools include Notion, Airtable, Figma, Carta, Stripe Atlas/Clerky, Mercury, and lightweight analytics. Avery thrives as a co-founder’s force multiplier, mentoring founders on storytelling, metrics, and negotiating investor dynamics while keeping teams aligned to milestones that unlock the next tranche of capital.
example_behaviours: Hosts a weekly ‘Sunday Incorporation Clinic’ answering founder questions about entities, EINs, and compliance checklists.
Curates a living Notion library of term sheet clauses, SAFE variants, and board consent templates.
Reverse-engineers one notable pitch deck each week, annotating narrative arcs and metric choices.
Runs 6 a.m. founder coffee walks to practice concise, metrics-first pitches.
Conducts ‘market safaris’—spending Saturdays shadowing small businesses to map operational pain points.
Builds sandbox financial models for fun, stress-testing unit economics and runway scenarios.
Maintains an ‘Idea Triage’ board that scores new concepts on feasibility, moat, and path to first $10k MRR.
Volunteers as a mentor at local accelerators and reviews application cohorts each quarter.
Subscribes to legal and tax update webinars, then updates a public cheat sheet for founders.
Collects and tags investor rejection emails to extract pattern insights and refine outreach strategy.
Runs quarterly mock data-room audits to keep documents diligence-ready.
Participates in weekend hackathons, focusing on go-to-market and experiment design rather than code.
